original: Johansson, Eric Felix Verner, fil. kand., läroverksadjunkt, Huskvarna, f. 14/1/83 i Ulrika, östergötl. 1., av J. M. Carls,son o. Mathilda Andersson. — Folksk :lär:ex. 04, stud:ex. 08, fil kand. i Lund 15. Res. t. Tyskl. o. Österr. 22. E. o. lär. i Huskvarna 12-15, ord. ämneslär. där 15, adj. i mo-dersm., hist. m. samh :lära o. matem. v. Huskvarna samrealsk. sed. 32, vik. rektor part. 32 o. 33. Led. av skolråd 17-20, led. av lokalstyr. f. Huskvarna samrealsk. sed. 34.
translated: Johansson, Eric Felix Verner, Bachelor of Arts, high school teacher, from Huskvarna, born on January 14, 1883 in Ulrika, Östergötland County, son of J. M. Carls and Mathilda Andersson. He obtained a teaching certificate in elementary school in 1904, and a bachelor's degree from Lund University in 1915. He traveled to Germany and Austria in 1922. He was a deputy teacher in Huskvarna from 1912 to 1915, and then a regular subject teacher there from 1915, teaching in the subjects of mother tongue, history, social science and mathematics at Huskvarna secondary school since 1932. He was acting principal in 1932 and 1933. He was a member of the school board from 1917 to 1920 and a member of the local government for Huskvarna secondary school since 1934. He married in 19xx, but no information on his partner is given.

structured.name: Eric Felix Verner Johansson

memberOf.name: Local Government for Huskvarna Secondary School

structured.description: Eric Felix Verner Johansson was a high school teacher from Huskvarna. He was born on January 14, 1883, in Ulrika, Östergötland County to J. M. Carls and Mathilda Andersson. He obtained a teaching certificate in elementary school in 1904 and a bachelor's degree from Lund University in 1915. He traveled to Germany and Austria in 1922. He worked as a deputy teacher in Huskvarna from 1912 to 1915 and then became a regular subject teacher there in 1915, teaching subjects like mother tongue, history, social science, and mathematics at Huskvarna secondary school since 1932. He was acting principal in 1932 and 1933.
